p.s: Description of Sulfurospirillum deleyianum sp. nov.
Sulfurospirillum deleyianum (De. ley. ja' num. M. L. neut. n. deleyianum named after J. De Ley, who significantly contributed to bacterial systematics based on genetic relationships)
Main characteristics are as described for the genus.
The following features are typical for the type strain.
Colonies in deep agar cultures are lens-shaped with a yellowish color caused by a flexirubin-type pigment.
Cells contain cytochrome b and c.

Anoxic growth occurs with hydrogen or formate as electron donor, acetate and hydrogen carbonate as carbon source and one of the following electron acceptors: nitrate, nitrite (reduced to ammonia), sulfite, thiosulfate, elemental sulfur (reduced to sulfide), dimethyl sulfoxide (reduced to dimethyl sulfide), fumarate, malate and aspartate (reduced to succinate).
The following substrates can be fermented: fumarate and malate.
Microaerobic growth with 1-4% oxygen but not in air.
Substrates utilized for microaerobic growth: succinate, fumarate, malate, aspartate, pyruvate, oxoglutarate, and oxaloacetate.
No oxidation of glycerol or acetate.
Assimilatory sulfate reduction lacking; a source of reduced sulfur, e.g. sulfide or L-cysteine, is required for growth.
No vitamins or amino acids required.
Temperature range for growth 20-36°C no growth at 42°C.
Isolated from anoxic mud of a forrest pond near Heiningen, Braunschweig area, FRG.
The mol% G + C of the DNA is 40.6 (HPLC). (Earlier determination 38.4, Tm).
